claim: Electronics have become more affordable in the US since 1990.

supporting.text: The average price of consumer electronics like televisions and computers has significantly decreased since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing and economies of scale.

attacks.text: The average price of consumer electronics like televisions and computers has significantly decreased since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing and economies of scale.
Inflation-adjusted prices for many electronics have remained stable or even increased when accounting for higher quality and features.
The decrease in prices is offset by shorter product lifespans and planned obsolescence, leading to higher long-term costs for consumers.
Historical price indices show a clear downward trend in real terms for core electronics categories, even after adjusting for quality improvements.
Many basic electronics models without premium features still show significant price drops when comparing equivalent products over time.
Product lifespans have actually increased for many electronics due to better materials and manufacturing standards.
The total cost of ownership has decreased as replacement cycles are offset by dramatically lower initial purchase prices.

supporting.text: Inflation-adjusted data shows that smartphones, which were non-existent in 1990, are now widely available at lower prices than early models when adjusted for technological improvements.

attacks.text: Inflation-adjusted data shows that smartphones, which were non-existent in 1990, are now widely available at lower prices than early models when adjusted for technological improvements.
Technological improvements may not fully account for the hidden costs of data plans and accessories, which increase the total cost of ownership.
Early adopters of new technologies often pay premium prices, skewing the comparison of affordability over time.
Data plans and accessories are optional and not required to use basic smartphone functionalities, so they should not be included in affordability comparisons.
The premium paid by early adopters is a temporary phenomenon and does not reflect the long-term trend of decreasing prices for mature technologies.

supporting.text: The proliferation of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down costs for electronics, making them more affordable for US consumers.

attacks.text: The proliferation of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down costs for electronics, making them more affordable for US consumers.
Increased tariffs and trade wars have disrupted global supply chains, leading to higher costs for electronics in the US.
Inflation and rising raw material costs have offset any savings from competition among manufacturers.
Many manufacturers have found ways to bypass tariffs by relocating production to countries not affected by trade wars.
Technological advancements have reduced the cost of raw materials, counteracting inflationary pressures.

supporting.text: The introduction of budget-friendly brands and direct-to-consumer sales models has further reduced prices, increasing accessibility.

attacks.text: The introduction of budget-friendly brands and direct-to-consumer sales models has further reduced prices, increasing accessibility.
Inflation-adjusted data shows that while nominal prices have decreased, real purchasing power for electronics has not significantly improved for many consumers.
Many budget-friendly brands compromise on quality or durability, leading to higher long-term costs for consumers.
Direct-to-consumer models often exclude lower-income households without reliable internet access or credit cards.
Studies show that even with inflation adjustments, the cost-performance ratio of electronics has improved dramatically since 1990.
Consumer reports indicate that many budget brands now meet or exceed the quality standards of premium brands from the 1990s.
Community programs and public libraries increasingly provide internet access and support for online purchases, mitigating the digital divide.

supporting.text: While some base models are cheaper, premium electronics (e.g., high-end laptops, OLED TVs) have seen price increases, offsetting overall affordability gains.

attacks.text: While some base models are cheaper, premium electronics (e.g., high-end laptops, OLED TVs) have seen price increases, offsetting overall affordability gains.
The average price of electronics has decreased significantly when adjusted for inflation, making them more accessible to the general population.
Technological advancements have increased the value and features of premium electronics, justifying their higher prices.
Inflation-adjusted data shows that even premium electronics are more affordable now due to higher average incomes and better financing options.
The cost of manufacturing high-end electronics has risen due to supply chain complexities and material costs, which explains the price increases.
Consumer demand for premium electronics has surged, allowing manufacturers to maintain higher prices without losing market share.

supporting.text: Hidden costs like subscription services, accessories, and planned obsolescence may reduce the long-term affordability of electronics despite lower upfront prices.

attacks.text: Hidden costs like subscription services, accessories, and planned obsolescence may reduce the long-term affordability of electronics despite lower upfront prices.
Many electronics now include essential features built-in, reducing the need for additional accessories and subscriptions.
Planned obsolescence is not unique to modern electronics and has been a factor in pricing for decades.
The availability of third-party accessories and competitive subscription pricing further mitigates hidden costs.
Consumer awareness and regulations have increased, reducing the impact of planned obsolescence.
